author: Talia Cotton
description: even more mathy. Wrote a function that *isn't fully working yet* but still does a lot. I wanted it to draw the arc between two input points, based on a height of the arc. In other words, the function determines how big to draw the circle, and in which direction, in order for it to pass through two points. I ALMOST got it. I know what's wrong -- I need to get the *length of the arc* between the two points, which is based off of the angle between the two points at the center of the circle. All of this is turtle graphics... i swear it's more complicated than it looks! (proof in pic#2). Just like the last sketch, this is all meant to set up the building blocks for doing more complex illustrations.

author: Kim Koehler
description:
This is my first shot at doing the "Kazimir Malevich Challange".

The video is my piece, every time I update the page a new random amount of objects appear in random forms and places. The colors are picked random but I used the "rollDice" technique to cancel out all the mid values of RGB. So all the values are either high or low. As it looks like those are the color palettes Malevich seems to use the most. Then a texture is added over the objects. This is how far I got in 2 hours. 

The two pictures are Malevich's, just for reference to compare to.

author: Talia Cotton
description:
Part 1. Getting it to play.

_______________________
Issues: Not sure why the buzzing sound is there. It gets worse the more the "instrument" is used.
_______________________

Short term goals: 

(1) Being able to play two notes at once. Now it's just updating the same oscillator, but I think I'll give each note its own oscillator.

(2) Adding "black keys" (One row above. Trying to make "playing" it as intuitive as playing a piano.)
_______________________

Long term goals:

(1) Making the "up"/"down" arrows control the key it's in. Right now the instrument is automatically playing in the key of C, but I want to add a function where the user shifts all sounds at once. Almost like Gershwin's piano.

(2) Adding visuals. "Play your own Painting" kind-of-thing.

author: Talia Cotton
description:
This was the first failed attempt at a fractal forest.
Method: First define number of trees. (randomly)
Then for each "tree", define the starting values for: x1, y1 ,x2 ,y2, length (random), and angle at each branch-off (random number between 0 and PI/2).
Then redefine the variables: length = length*0.67, x1 = x2; y1 = y2; ... and then x2 and y2 are then redefined by finding the sine and cosine of the angle and multiplying by the new length. (+/-)... etc.
The result was a big beautiful huge failure! :D
Will revisit this later on in the assignment.... I'll give it one more chance.

description: Haiku generator... Writing poems never came this easy back in English class . Haiku generally follows the 5-7-5 syllables rule on three lines, and usually describe nature related things. Ways to improve it includes 1) More sentence structure variety 2)More vocab 3)Work it with a better background other than the simple gradient.

author: Talia Cotton
description:
AMBER & SANIE (And anyone else who was having trouble with the "counter") --

I'm not sure what your respective codes look like, so likely you've tried this already. But just in case, this was very helpful for me to include a counter.

In the draw() function, include:

------
text("sprite count: " + allSprites.length,
    width-10, 10);

------

(The second line just positions where the text is. It doesn't have to be "width-10, 10". That just makes it appear in the top right corner. But I think those parameters have to be filled which is why I kept it in.)

"allSprites" is an *awesome* tool that counts however many sprites there are in the canvas. (See the "Inspired by" link above.)

Then whenever you have the *action* that counts (anything, like clicking or capturing or whatever) you don't have to do anything to the "counter"! All you do is get rid of a "sprite". This makes it much easier... 

Hope this helps!!!

Good luck!

author: Talia Cotton
description:
Some explanatory videos on my progress on the development of the keyboard's functions.

Tl;dr. I made a keyboard that adds harmonic notes automatically to the melody, determined by whichever degree of the original key is being played. 


This works for many reasons and solves a few problems: 

(1) **For educational purposes,** it really forces the student to understand what a "degree" *sounds* like, so they're able to start recognizing them faster. Super important! 

(2) **For visual purposes,** it makes the visuals *really* reflect the "sound" of the song. The computer now has a better understanding of what key something is in, whether it's major or minor, and the relation of chords within the song, so it's able to treat the visuals differently so every piece looks unique. 

(3) For utilitarian purposes, the computer keyboard is very small proportionally compared to a piano. The added function to add harmonic notes automatically opens up options, giving the player more *literal* flexibility to be swifter when playing the melody.

author: Talia Cotton
description:
Experimentation less with shape, more with color.
I made the stroke color go up within the loop by whatever percentage of the loop "i" was, so that it finished the whole rainbow by the time the loop was finished.
What I was struggling with was as soon as the noLoop() was commented out, it didn't work this way... it was all red. So if I wanted to make a moving thing it didn't work this way.
My alternative for the motion ones was to create a function within draw() so that OVER TIME the color went through a gradient... but that's still not exactly right. (so basically each frame had a solid color, but the solid color changed gradually.)
I don't know what to fix...the logic of the loops seems right but visually it's not coming out... /// the second one uses i "to the power of" ///
The last one was accidental, kinda cool...

author: Talia Cotton
description: **(2/3)** **[PIC 1:]** Thanks to lots of help from Justin, and to some practice with lerp from the line challenge, I was able to rethink the line in terms of control points, and a relaxation between them. Now I needed to resolve the slope problem! **[PIC 2:] Slope problem resolved!** This was the most exciting moment during the whole process. The solution was to rotate each individually according to the arctan of the angle between the x and y of the slope: rotate(atan(path_points[i+1].y - path_points[i-1].y)/(path_points[i+1].x - path_points[i-1].x)); **[PIC 3]** Using some blend modes and random min/max functions to give the canvas a parchment-looking effect with cool edges.

author: Justin Bakse
description:
For a project I'm working on, I need a way to create an input map that would tell me how far down a color path each pixel is from a starting point. I used p5 to build a little tool to create the maps.

This first video shows the tool tracing out a path in a little maze. Black pixels are near the middle, the color becomes more red as you travel down the path.

The second video shows a test that uses the map to control how much of a plasma effect is shown.

author: Justin Bakse
description:
Snow day today. This sketch builds up in a few layers.

First, It draws a layer of ground snow and some random snowmen.

Then, It draws a transparent blue rectangle over the whole scene, pushing it back.

It then draws a couple of more layers of ground snow and snowmen.

Last, it draws the snow in the air and a sort of static-y vignette.


You can view the source on [codepen](http://codepen.io/jbakse/pen/WRaKjG?editors=0010).

description:
These ones are all cheating because I did them a long time ago, but I thought I'd share anyway.

The first image is a pixel sorted / feedback glitched version of a famous photo by Anwar Hossain, one of my favorite Bangladeshi photographers.

The second video is of a Koncakowski GIF that I did a glitch animation of. If you haven't checked out Koncakowski's stuff before, he makes pretty crazy fractal-like endlessly looping GIFs.

The third video is one of the earliest pixel sorting pieces I made with that particular technique / approach.

author: Talia Cotton
description:
A shot at the treasure map challenge. And now for the journal entry:
**WHAT'S WORKING:** (1) cool background texture due to noise in HSB values; (2) the uneven edges of the map creating a "ripped" texture, using noise to draw a shape with *different noise seeds* (because they were all looking like the same rip for a really long time); (3) A noisey dotted line generated from noise. (4) The "X". (not by noise.) **WHAT COULD BE BETTER:** (1) Preferably the line would be a little less "linear";  (2) And also preferably the dots on the line would be evenly spaced apart, not by their x-axis but by their location on the line. Maybe this is related to: (3) Was trying to get the line to be less "dotted" and more "dashed" but I couldn't figure out how to make the dashes go in the direction of the line (they would all go according to one static slope.) Hmm...

author: Kim Koehler
description:
CLICK THE VIDEO
If you choose to not fill your GPU(Graphics Processing Unit) with any media when printing it to the screen, there will be a bunch of random information stored in the memory from the last times you've used the GPU memory. This code is moving through the bits of the memory in the GPU while showing what is stored there. The stored information creates this cool "glitch art". It moves according to the rules of Brownian Motion.  The red line moving around on the screen shows the movements between the bits. GPU size in relation to the sketch size. To highlight "where" in the memory we are at the moment. Maybe a bit to conceptual..
The collage picture was cool findings I found in my GPU but that I didn't catch on video.

Inspiration was Brownian Motion and Images in Cinder by Joshua  Noble. "https://libcinder.org/docs/guides/cinder-images/index.html#surface"

3D set of 64 cubes...
Playing with calculating the number of subsets of a set with n elements. Can be represented by a 6-digit binary string...

2^6 (faces of cube) = 64 combinations
Now that I have the set the step will be....... PLAYING WITH THEM YAY!

author: Talia Cotton
description:
Tried out some Chromatic Aberration. // 
The process was pretty straightforward: Load the image three times into three "channels" (r.g.b) (for example, redChannel would be (*red_pixel_value*, 0 ,0). I used blendMode EXCLUSION, then I positioned each image on top of one another between random(-2,2) offset. (You can see the variation in the last pic.) // 
Some troubles I encountered were mostly about the image size.  It was working perfectly for .get()/.set() functions for smaller images, but it took a while to rewrite the getQuick() function to reprint the image (the way it was written in Justin's documentation didn't work exactly for re"setting()" the image, only when you're reading the image values to build a whole new one. // Going forward it would be cool to try to "wave" the output images a bit. Already starting thinking, but ran out of time.

author: Talia Cotton
description: Getting mathy again... Tried to build a visual representation of 3D parametric equations. (For example, the first one is what sin(x) looks like. And a sphere *actually* looks like the expressions in pic #2. Cool, huh!) The mouse scroll controls the rotation of the image. I reeeally struggled with letting the user toggle between them! At first I wanted buttons at the top with the equations that the user could click, then visualize, but that would be 2D + 3D rendering, and from what I understand Vuo doesn't allow that? Then I settled for having the user click numbers on the keyboard to toggle, but I couldn't get it to erase the last one. Tried the "Cycle Through List" node but that didn't help. Hmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm....

author: Talia Cotton
description:
Two Player Game.

If you get shot you lose a point.

But also if you shoot you lose a point.

So basically whoever is fastest to shoot on the *very last* shoot is the winner. It could go both ways... players could play really quickly (vid 1) and see who wins, or they could get slower and slower to the end and then it's a Prisoner's dilemma type of situation. (vid 2)

description:
Party Time! 
Made a random confetti generator. Some fun play with bezier curves and handles (see pic 3). Tried to create an "organic" feel to the squiggle confetti by altering the y-height of each loop. (In retrospect maybe I should have used the Arc function for the straight line confetti with a very short arc height, just to make it even more windy / bendy / natural-looking.) Future of this sketch could be: adding animation, making an "exploding" motion, making it appear on every click in a circle around the mouse, etc.

Third iteration of a series of experiments that are to lead to the synthesis of a parametric flower. Getting much closer to the final goal. The version of the video where some of the splines are colored is meant to illustrate the kind of things I am trying out to troubleshoot (I much prefer the b&w look for this piece).

*all the bezier points can be controlled in realtime, but I am waiting to expose the parametric control once the final iteration has been reached so that I can reveal a specific effect that I am working towards

author: Talia Cotton
description:
In class we were given many methods for generating text: Markov chains, the Underscore library, etc. While they were fun to implement, I didn't think I was gaining an understanding of how a computer organizes language syntax---I was only plugging in words to a pre-written function. So I wanted to begin thinking about other methods, to really push my understanding...


In this attempt (which would naturally need more time to get perfected) the user inputs text, and the computer identifies all the verbs and nouns. (I used the Compromise library for that part.) Then it picks a noun (in its singular form) and its article, a verb (in present tense), and another noun, making a very simple noun-verb-noun sentence.


This is flawed in soooo many ways. 


Ideally I would find a way for it to distinguish between transitive and intransitive verbs, to figure out if a noun after the verb really makes sense. I would also identify all parts of speech in the text, then have the computer decide which sentence structure is most common and generate a sentence like that.


Anyway, it's a little different, but fun.

author: Justin Bakse
description:
I like some of what is happening in this, but I'd like to change a few things.

1. It would be better if it had a better "beginning".
2. The middle is two spastic, I think it would work better if the noise displacement was stronger, but changed more slowly.
3. The outro needs an ease-in.

How this is built: The core of this is a ring of ellipses. There are very many ellipses, very closely packed, so you lose sight of the individual shapes. You can see this more clearly in the less tightly packed ellipses in the outer ring.

I use noise displacement to offset some of the ellipses more than others. The blendMode is ADD, and the ellipses are very dark, this lets them build up a glow. The sketch is white on black, which is easier to think about than full color. The color is added in photoshop with a gradient map.

[Code on JSBin](http://jsbin.com/kikaluc/edit?js,output)

description: very mathy.  Inspired by the many differently-sized and positioned circles that came out when students were asked to draw a circle for the in-class circle challenge. (Size matters!!)
